nodes.text: Human capacity for processing information in absolute judgments is limited and can be characterized by a channel capacity measured in bits
Map amount of information to variance and transmitted information to covariance or input-output correlation following information theory
Absolute judgment experiments treat the observer as a communication channel: input = stimulus variance, output = response variance, overlap = transmitted information
Unidimensional stimulus channel capacities cluster in a narrow range around a mean of about 2.6 bits (SD 0.6), corresponding roughly to 4 to 10 distinguishable categories and a total range 3 to 15
Pitch absolute judgments (Pollack): transmitted information rises then asymptotes at about 2.5 bits, i.e. about six perfectly discriminable pitch categories
Other unidimensional results: loudness ~2.3 bits (~5 categories), taste concentration ~1.9 bits (~4 categories), visual position in interval ~3.25 bits (10-15 positions), curvature as low as 1.6 bits
Conclusion: there is a relatively small, finite span for unidimensional absolute judgments likely rooted in perceptual or learning constraints of the nervous system
Limitation of unidimensional span can be overcome by increasing stimulus dimensionality, making relative judgments, or using sequences of judgments (successive discriminations)
Multidimensional stimuli increase channel capacity but with diminishing returns; added dimensions raise total capacity while reducing accuracy per dimension
Examples of multidimensional results: dot-in-square (2D) ~4.6 bits (~24 positions), combined saltiness and sweetness 2.3 bits vs salt alone 1.9, pitch plus loudness 3.1 bits vs individual 2.5 and 2.3

High-dimensional auditory experiment (Pollack and Ficks): six independent acoustic variables each with five values produced transmitted information ~7.2 bits, about 150 identifiable categories; an 8-dim binary design yielded ~6.9 bits (~120 categories)
Immediate memory (span of immediate memory) is limited by number of chunks (about seven items) rather than by a fixed number of bits per span
Experimental evidence (Hayes, Pollack): span varies little with bits per item; transmitted information increases almost linearly with bits per item, showing items count (chunks) is primary limiter
Recoding or chunking can increase bits per chunk and thus increase total information retained; demonstrated by binary-to-higher-base recoding experiments (Smith) and mnemonic practice
Result: With practiced recoding, a subject memorized many more binary digits (e.g., 40) by grouping into larger chunks (octal, decimal names), showing recoding power to extend memory capacity

Conclusions and implications: information theory provides quantitative measures useful for discrimination, language, learning and memory; recoding is vital for cognition; the coincident appearance of the number seven across domains may be largely coincidental
